results.title: Gone Home
results.brief_description: When Katie returns home from overseas, she finds her house deserted and her family gone. That’s just one horror trope that Gone Home uses to mislead players as Katie searches the house for her family in this walking simulator.

constellations_primary.name: Teens, zines and 90s scenes
constellations_primary.description: Exploring representations of teen life and culture.

results.description:
When Katie returns home from overseas, she finds her house deserted and her family gone.

That’s just one horror trope that Gone Home uses to mislead players as Katie searches the house for her family. Unlike typical games, Gone Home features minimal activity and was an early ‘walking simulator’, with the story unfolding at the player’s own pace as they examine notes and objects, rather than relying on traditional exposition.

Developed by indie studio Fullbright, Gone Home was highly praised by critics and fans for its unique style and positive representation of LGBTQIA+ themes.

results.title: National Portable Video Camera WV-3085
results.brief_description: The Portapak system is a handheld video camera with separate reel-to-reel video recorder. It enabled videos to be captured and played back more quickly while also cutting down on the cost, which led to the birth of video art, guerrilla television and activism.

constellations_primary.name: Access to resistance
constellations_primary.description: This Constellation explores how access to new recording devices has inspired guerilla filmmaking and protest, helping challenge cultural, societal and political norms.

results.description: The Portapak system consists of a handheld video camera with a separate reel-to-reel video recorder in a portable pack that could be carried over the shoulder. The style was first released by Sony in 1967 and was an important development in camera technology, enabling a new level of portability with both the camera and recorder battery-powered and self-contained. It enabled videos to be captured and played back more quickly while also cutting down on the cost, which led to the birth of video art, guerrilla television and activism. In the 1970s, the Portapak was popular with video artists and alternative media collectives. In Australia, Open Channel and the Paddington Video Access Centre used Portapaks to create alternative broadcast channels, paving the way for community television.
description_for_label: The Portapak system consists of a handheld video camera with a separate reel-to-reel video recorder in a portable pack that could be carried over the shoulder. The style was first released by Sony in 1967 and was an important development in camera technology, enabling a new level of portability with both the camera and recorder battery-powered and self-contained. It enabled videos to be captured and played back more quickly while also cutting down on the cost, which led to the birth of video art, guerrilla television and activism. In the 1970s, the Portapak was popular with video artists and alternative media collectives. In Australia, Open Channel and the Paddington Video Access Centre used Portapaks to create alternative broadcast channels, paving the way for community television.

results.title: VFX in American Gods
results.credit_line:
Title sequence creative director: Patrick Clair
Courtesy Fremantle
results.brief_description: A look at the acclaimed title sequence from American Gods, by VFX studio Antibody.

constellations_primary.name: The world's end
constellations_primary.description: For people of colour oppressed by systemic racism, genre stories about the end of the world and cosmological monsters can be used to re-examine race and the injustices faced in real life.

results.description: Growing up in a Catholic home, Patrick Clair was used to seeing religious iconography. Little did he know he would one day have the opportunity to merge and subvert it with his work at motion graphics studio Antibody, alongside Raoul Marks. Having redefined the art of opening credits during the peak TV era, American Gods (2017–present) saw the Antibody team mix religious and patriotic symbolism together for their most daring work yet as they brought the mythologies of Neil Gaiman’s source material to life.
description_for_label:
Growing up in a Catholic home, Patrick Clair was used to seeing religious iconography. Little did he know he would one day have the opportunity to merge and subvert it with his work at motion graphics studio Antibody, alongside Raoul Marks. Having redefined the art of opening credits during the peak TV era, American Gods (2017–present) saw the Antibody team mix religious and patriotic symbolism together for their most daring work yet as they brought the mythologies of Neil Gaiman’s source material to life.

No photography

Courtesy Fremantle

results.title: Portable TVs (Retro Vision)
results.brief_description: Australians loved portable TVs. How else could you watch cricket at the beach or take your favourite show camping? Despite how portable these units were, due to using batteries, their small stature saw them positioned in the home just as much as the great outdoors, and they gradually became more of a fashion statement during the late 1970s and 80s. The most fashionable of the ones displayed here is easily the JVC Videosphere, which came in red, black, white and orange, and was designed to look like a space helmet, in homage to 2001: A Space Odyssey and the popularity of the Space Race in 1970 when it was released. It’s since appeared as props in Hollywood films and in video artist Nam June Paik’s installation, TV Buddha (1974).

results.title: 8mm Film
results.brief_description: The relatively low cost of 8mm film and its production made filmmaking more accessible to both amateurs, artist and filmmakers. The addition of a magnetic sound for this format in the 1960s let users record sound while filming and add narration in later as well. A typical 8mm filmmaking suite includes a camera, projector, editing equipment and film splicers, some of which are in this display. What’s not shown is how many we actually have in the collection as we’re increasingly offered these types of objects through donations.

results.title: Early home consoles
results.brief_description: While the first home console, the Magnavox Odyssey, came out in 1972, it wasn’t the only launched in the decade. Around 1978, the two-player Hanimex TVG-8610C console was released for home use. Featuring detachable joysticks and 10 internally programmed games, it allowed players to customise difficulty levels, automation and keep score. Console like this needed to be run through the home TV to use as a monitor and also required a little domestic diplomacy with family members for a bigger share of screen time.

results.title: Commodore 64 Console and Cassettes
results.brief_description: Consoles and personal computers are common in homes today, but back in 1982 they were pretty rare. Enter the Commodore 64, a wildly popular 8-bit home computer console that was a major contributor to the home computer revolution. With over 17 million units sold worldwide, it was the highest selling single computer at the time and was often used to run educational resources and games. In Australia alone, over 700 games were produced for the Commodore 64. Software was originally released on audio cassette before 5 ¼ inch floppy discs (and later 3½ inch floppy discs) became more common during the 1980s, which we’ve worked to locate, acquire and preserve.

results.title: VFX in Thor: Ragnarok
results.brief_description: Adelaide-based VFX company Rising Sun Pictures were entrusted with a pivotal moment in Thor: Ragnaork, where Tessa Thompson’s character recounts the fatal encounter between the Valkyrie warriors and the Asgardian Goddess of Death, Hela (Cate Blanchett).

constellations_primary.name: Superhero special effects
constellations_primary.description: VFX talent isn't limited to just one studio that makes superhero blockbusters.

results.description: One of Thor: Ragnarok‘s (2017) most heartbreaking moments also happens to be one of its most beautiful. Adelaide-based visual effects company Rising Sun Pictures were entrusted with a pivotal moment where Tessa Thompson’s character recounts the fatal encounter between the Valkyrie warriors and the Asgardian Goddess of Death, Hela. The flashback plays out in artful slow motion, with the carnage captured under glittering light thanks to an innovative lighting rig designed by Satellite Lab to create high-speed changes in lighting. Rising Sun Pictures have built an international reputation for their expertise in slow motion visual effects, which were also seen in X-Men: Days of Future Past (2014).
description_for_label: One of Thor: Ragnarok‘s most heartbreaking moments is also one of its most beautiful. Adelaide-based VFX company Rising Sun Pictures created the pivotal moment where Tessa Thompson’s character recounts the fatal encounter between the Valkyrie warriors and the Asgardian Goddess of Death, Hela. The flashback happens in artful slow motion, with the carnage captured under glittering light thanks to an innovative lighting rig designed by Satellite Lab to create high-speed changes in lighting. Rising Sun Pictures also demonstrated their expertise in slow-motion VFX in X-Men: Days of Future Past.

results.title: VFX in JoJo Rabbit
results.credit_line:
VFX Supervisor: Brendan Seals
Courtesy Luma Pictures and Fox Searchlight Pictures
results.brief_description: Visual effects studio Luma Pictures helped Taika Waititi realise his creative vision for Jojo Rabbit by replacing contemporary elements in scenes with period-accurate ones that represent WWII Germany.

constellations_primary.name: Undercutting extremism with absurdity
constellations_primary.description: Taika Waititi's satirical performance as Adolf Hitler in Jojo Rabbit connects to a number of other portrayals that includes ill-fated (and conceived) TV shows, memes, high camp and cinema classics.

results.description: The world through a child’s eyes is a unique thing, even more so when that child is created by Academy Award-nominee Taika Waititi. Visual effects studio Luma Pictures helped Waititi realise his creative vision for Jojo Rabbit. Luma Pictures took street scenes filmed in the present-day Czech Republic and made them more historically appropriate for World War II Germany. Removing contemporary elements and replacing them with period-accurate ones is subtle work, but it helps weave the tapestry of Jojo’s reality: both real and imagined.
description_for_label: The world through a child’s eyes is a unique thing, even more so when that child is created by Academy Award-nominee Taika Waititi. Visual effects studio Luma Pictures helped Waititi realise his creative vision for Jojo Rabbit. Courtesy Luma Pictures and Fox Searchlight Pictures
